title: Johannes Pullois
text:
Johannes Pullois (numerous variant spellings of his name include Pillays, Pilloys, Pylois, Pyloys, Pyllois, Puilloys, Puylloys, Puyllois) (died 23 August 1478) was a <a href="Dutch%20School%20%28music%29">Franco-Flemish</a> composer of the <a href="Renaissance%20music">Renaissance</a>, active in both the <a href="Low%20Countries">Low Countries</a> and <a href="Italy">Italy</a>. He was one of the early generation of composers to carry the Franco-Flemish <a href="polyphony">polyphonic</a> style from its home region in the Netherlands to Italy.
He was probably born in <a href="Zandhoven">Pulle</a>, near <a href="Antwerp">Antwerp</a>, but nothing is known about his life until he became "zangmeester" (singing master) at the church of Our Lady in Antwerp in 1443. He unsuccessfully auditioned with <a href="Philip%20the%20Good">Philip the Good</a> for the <a href="Burgundian%20school">Burgundian</a> court chapel, but was not accepted for a position; he then in 1447 went to <a href="Rome">Rome</a>, where he sang in the papal chapel until 1468. He returned to Antwerp, becoming residential canon at the same church at which he had worked in the 1440s, and he died there in 1478. During his career he was a colleague of both <a href="Johannes%20Philibert">Johannes Philibert</a> and <a href="Johannes%20Ockeghem">Johannes Ockeghem</a>.
Music and influence.
One complete <a href="cyclic%20mass">cyclic mass</a> has survived, a "Missa sine nomine", for three voices; most likely dating from the 1450s, it is one of the earliest cyclic <a href="mass%20%28music%29">mass</a>es to be written on the continent. It shows such influence of English music that it has been mistaken for the work of an anonymous English composer. The mass displays a complex transmission pattern, which has confused its dating and provenance.
Pullois also wrote a <a href="motet">motet</a> for the Christmas season "Flos de spina", which is similar stylistically to works by <a href="Ockeghem">Ockeghem</a>, and may have been written during his time in Italy. One other motet, "Victime paschali laudes", and three sacred <a href="contrafacta">contrafacta</a> of secular songs have survived.
He also wrote 14 secular songs (including the three with contrafactum texts) which appear in various sources from Italy as well as Germany.
